name: rubus-trivialis
country-or-region-of-origin: Eastern United States (mid-Atlantic and south), west to Texas
wildlife-value: Excellent cover year round for birds and small mammals. Butterflies and other insects are attracted to the blooms for nectar. Fruits are eaten by songbirds and other animals. White-tailed deer and rabbits browse the leaves.
edibility: Can be eaten raw or cooked and is typically used in jams and preserves. The fruit is large, juicy, and sweet.
light: Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Fruits are available April-May and are black in color
flower-description: The white flowers are are usually solitary at the ends of short flowering branches. Flowers bloom March-June.
leaf-description: This plant has red and winter foliage.
stem-description: The young stems of Southern Dewberry usually have sharp bristles and prickles. The trailing stems have glandular bristles.
uses: The flowers are a popular nectar source for many insects.
